captions.text: Our test car has a speedometer,
An RPM gauge,
And an engine that explodes at 200 RPM.
Let’s push it to its limits…
It reached the maximal speed of 16 km/h in 8 seconds.
Let’s study our engine.
The gear attached to it exerts a certain amount of force.
This force can lift 20 kg…
But not 40 kg.
A visualization trick will help us choose the right gears.
This orange flare represents energy.
To be more precise, let’s mark the distance our force crosses in one second,
And multiply this by its magnitude.
This is our engine’s power: the amount of energy it unleashes every second.
At this RPM the power is about 40 watts.
Power is transmitted from gear to gear.
Assuming no friction, all 40 watts reach the last gear,
and it exerts the same amount of force.
In this arrangement of gears, the last gear’s teeth are moving slower.
Since energy cannot disappear,
our 40 watts will now produce a double amount of force.
A gear ratio of 2:1 creates this effect.
In our car, the engine’s power is transmitted to the back wheels.
Each wheel gets half of it.
The force exerted by the wheels accelerates the car.
Our new car has a 2:1 gear ratio in its gearbox,
doubling its acceleration.
Let’s compare the cars.
We’ll visualize power,
but this time show the amount of energy produced every 0.1 second.
This is now 400 watts.
That’s better acceleration, but worse maximal speed.
We can rearrange the gears to get the reverse effect...
... less force - more speed.
Our final car has a gear stick.
Allowing the driver to switch between low gear, as in the second car…
Medium gear, as in the first car…
And the new high gear.

title: Cars: engine power and transmission - 3D animation

comments.author: El Chaarawy

comments.text:
Energy can be seen as a product of force and distance, hence the graphs of 
force (red arrow) and distance (white arrow) resulting in a shaded region 
representing energy, the product, or area, of force and distance. Power is 
the ratio of energy to time, and when the gears are connected to each 
other, they transfer the same amount of energy to each other over time. The 
power that one gear has will be the same as any other in the chain.

Since energy cannot be created or destroyed, changing one of the factors of 
that energy will not affect the overall energy being put out over time. At 
any given point in time, the energy that the first gear spends is the same 
as that of the last in the chain. This means that when one factor is 
lacking, the other factor will simply compensate. This is a very simple way 
of saying that if we found a way to connect the gears and add one that *slows 
one of the gears down* so that the overall *distance* that the gear sweeps 
out over time is reduced, it will produce a greater *force,* since energy 
is just the product of energy and force.

comments.author: npataya

comments.text:
+npataya There are tons of formulas related to this, since there are tons 
of concepts involved: forces, energy, velocity, radial velocity, radius, 
torque. You can see for example here: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gear_train, though it's not easy reading.

The video tries to avoid many of the complexities, and focus on one 
property, and one formula:
If a gear's tooth is travelling distance X1 and exerting force F1, then it 
generates energy E=F1 X1. 
If the car (or weight, or whatever is moving in the end), is moving a 
different distance X2, then it experiences a different force F2. Because of 
energy conservation we know that F2 X2 = F1 X1,
Or F2 = F1 X1 / X2.

So if you add some gears that cause a distance of X1 in the engine source 
gear to be translated to smaller distance in the final car wheels, say 
X2=X1/2, then the original force F1 is doubled.

comments.author: npataya

comments.text:
If there's just a bunch of gears connected in a row, they don't help. When 
the first gear  (the one attached to the engine) tooth moves one 
centimeter, it pushes the next gear's tooth by one centimeter, which pushes 
the next gear's tooth by one centimeter, which eventually should lift the 
weight by one centimeter. So it's just the same as connecting the first 
gear directly.

You can see at 1:47, where the distance each tooth covers is tracked by a 
visual aid, that they're all covering the same distance. 

At 2:00 there's a different arrangement, where for each centimeter the 
first gear's tooth is moving, the last gear's tooth is moving only 1/2 a 
centimeter. This allows the same amount of energy to produce a double 
amount of force.
